passage_list.text:
The morning of Schaefer’s arrival on the ice sheet, three weeks earlier, was luminous and still. Barely a breeze jostled the helicopter that carried him to the field camp in northwest Greenland. Beneath him, the glittering expanse of the Prudhoe Dome ice cap resembled the ocean: Beautiful. Mysterious. Mind-bendingly huge.
Theoretically, Schaefer had already grasped this. The dome’s size was one reason it had been selected as a GreenDrill sampling site—the first of three strategic locations around Greenland where he and his colleagues planned to drill for bedrock samples over the next few years. Yet Schaefer was still stunned as the helicopter touched down on the dome’s summit. Despite a decades-long career in polar science, this was his first time on an ice sheet. 'It’s a monster,' he thought. Schaefer tried to imagine all that ice melting and flowing into the ocean. The catastrophic possibility made him shiver.

He knew that such a disaster had happened before. In 2016, Schaefer and his close colleague Jason Briner, GreenDrill’s co-director and a geology professor at the University at Buffalo, were part of a team that analyzed the single bedrock sample that had been previously collected from beneath the thickest part of the ice sheet. The rock contained chemical signatures showing it had been exposed to the sky in the past 1.1 million years. In a paper they published in the journal Nature, the scientists concluded that almost all of Greenland—including regions now covered by ice more than a mile deep—must have melted at least once within that time frame.
'That was a game changer,' said Neil Glasser, a glaciologist at Aberystwyth University who has followed Schaefer’s research. 'It said that the Greenland Ice Sheet is far more dynamic than we had ever thought.'

The findings ran counter to many scientists’ belief that Greenland has been relatively stable throughout recent geologic history, as the Earth oscillated between ice ages and milder warm periods known as interglacials. If the ice sheet could melt at a time when global temperatures never got much higher than they are now, it was a worrying harbinger of what ongoing human-caused warming might bring.
For Schaefer and Briner, the discovery also underscored how bedrock could complement findings from ice cores—the long slices of frozen material that had traditionally been the focus of polar science. For decades, scientists had studied air bubbles trapped in ice to uncover crucial clues about the climate at the time the ice formed.
Yet ice cores, by their very nature, could only reveal what happened during the colder phases of Earth’s history. They couldn’t answer what Schaefer said is arguably the most important question facing humanity now: 'What happened when it got warm?'

With GreenDrill—which is funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation—he and Briner aimed to open up a new kind of record, one that didn’t melt away. By collecting bedrock samples from around the island, they could gain a clearer picture of exactly when the ice sheet last vanished and what parts of Greenland melted first.
But to get those rocks, they would need to survive for more than a month in one of the most remote and hostile places on Earth.
The effort was shaping up to be harder than anyone had anticipated. It took seven plane trips for the team to haul GreenDrill’s equipment onto the ice sheet. Twice they were delayed by blizzards. Then a windstorm halted work on the drill for three full days.
The scientists who oversaw camp setup—Lamont Doherty geologist Nicolás Young and University at Buffalo Ph.D. student Caleb Walcott—already looked exhausted as they welcomed Schaefer to the ice.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of the first passage?

options.A: The beauty of the Prudhoe Dome ice cap
options.B: Schaefer’s first experience on an ice sheet
options.D: The process of drilling for bedrock samples

questions.explanation: The passage primarily describes Schaefer’s first experience on an ice sheet, including his awe at its size and his thoughts about its potential melting.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the main subject and the emotions or thoughts of the central character to identify the primary focus.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the Greenland Ice Sheet from the 2016 study?

options.A: It has always been stable throughout history.
options.B: It has melted completely at least once in the past 1.1 million years.
options.C: It is less dynamic than previously thought.
options.D: It contains no evidence of past climate changes.

questions.explanation: The study found that the Greenland Ice Sheet had melted at least once in the past 1.1 million years, as evidenced by the chemical signatures in the bedrock sample.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use specific evidence from the text to support your inferences.

questions.question: As used in the passage, the word 'harbinger' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: In this context, 'harbinger' refers to a sign or warning of what ongoing human-caused warming might bring.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for context clues in the surrounding sentences to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words.

questions.question: Which evidence best supports the idea that the GreenDrill project was challenging?

options.A: The team had to make seven plane trips to transport equipment.
options.B: The camp was equipped with propane stoves and a space heater.
options.C: The scientists planned to drill for bedrock samples.
options.D: The ice sheet was described as 'mind-bendingly huge.'

questions.explanation: The seven plane trips and delays due to blizzards and windstorms highlight the logistical challenges of the project.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Choose evidence that directly supports the main idea or claim being made.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the third passage?

options.A: To explain the limitations of ice cores
options.B: To describe the history of Greenland’s ice sheet
options.C: To argue for the importance of bedrock samples
options.D: To compare ice ages and interglacial periods

questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes the importance of bedrock samples in understanding past warm periods, which ice cores cannot reveal.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the main argument or purpose by looking for repeated ideas or conclusions.

questions.question: What does Neil Glasser’s statement imply about the Greenland Ice Sheet?

options.A: It is less stable than previously believed.
options.B: It has never melted in the past.
options.C: It is unaffected by global warming.
options.D: It is the largest ice sheet in the world.

questions.explanation: Glasser’s statement that the ice sheet is 'far more dynamic than we had ever thought' implies that it is less stable than previously believed.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to expert opinions or quotes, as they often provide key insights.

questions.question: As used in the passage, the word 'luminous' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: In this context, 'luminous' describes the bright and clear morning light.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the surrounding description to infer the meaning of descriptive words.

questions.question: What was the main goal of the GreenDrill project?

options.A: To study air bubbles in ice cores
options.B: To collect bedrock samples from Greenland
options.C: To measure the thickness of the ice sheet
options.D: To analyze the effects of blizzards on drilling

questions.explanation: The GreenDrill project aimed to collect bedrock samples to understand when the ice sheet last vanished.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for explicit statements about the purpose or goal of a project or study.

questions.question: How does the author use the 2016 study to support the main idea of the passage?

options.A: By showing that Greenland’s ice sheet has always been stable
options.B: By demonstrating the limitations of ice core research
options.C: By providing evidence that the ice sheet has melted in the past
options.D: By arguing that bedrock samples are unnecessary

questions.explanation: The 2016 study provides evidence that the ice sheet has melted in the past, supporting the idea that it is more dynamic than previously thought.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how evidence is used to support or develop the main idea.

questions.question: Which statement best supports the idea that ice cores have limitations?

options.A: Ice cores can only reveal what happened during colder phases.
options.B: Ice cores are difficult to collect from remote locations.
options.C: Ice cores provide information about air bubbles.
options.D: Ice cores are the primary focus of polar science.

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that ice cores can only reveal information about colder phases, not warm periods.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Choose evidence that directly addresses the limitations or strengths of a method or idea.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning. They can infer complex meanings, analyze text structure, and evaluate evidence effectively.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis. They can identify main ideas and details but may miss subtle inferences or complex text structures.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning, analyze complex text structures, or evaluate evidence.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas, details, and word meanings.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit information in the text.
